option.name: name
option.value: Hello World

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Content changed

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
The first program any programmer makes in any language is "Hello, world". It displays the phrase "Hello, world" on the screen. I've written one up in Java for you. Try to run it!

There are a lot of challenges to a "Hello, world" program that aren't really applicable when developing in an IDE, but it still tells you that Java is correctly installed on your computer, which is important!

option.name: name
option.value: Running a Program

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Up to date

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Sometimes, you'll want to use code you didn't write. There are a lot of reasons you might want to do this. Usually it's because you're trying to do something hard, and someone has already solved the problem for you

Of course, not all code is good, so you should make sure the source is credible, but that's beyond the scope of this task.

To use someone else's code, you just have to import it

An IDE like IntelliJ IDEA often automatically inserts an import statement, but you should still understand how to do it by hand.

option.name: name
option.value: Understanding Imports

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Up to date

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: // import statement

option.name: possibleAnswer
option.value: import java.util.Random;
